Herein, chitosan as an inexpensive, abundant, and biodegradable bio-material, produced from a key constituent of the exoskeletons of crustaceans, was used to generate the cobalt-based magnetic silica nanocomposite for the performance of the C-N cross-coupling reaction as the main step of the synthesis of Abemaciclib and Fedratinibs. Several derivatives of these recently FDA-approved anti-cancer drugs were synthesized for the first time by using Pd/Cu-free co-catalyzed under both, the conventional heating and microwave (MW) irradiation conditions. The potential anticancer activity of synthesized compounds was investigated by molecular docking study. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Abemaciclib Fedratinib C-N cross-coupling Magnetic catalyst Molecular docking Introduction Recently, C-N cross-coupling reactions have attracted much attentions as an important strategy for the construction of organic compounds. These reactions have extensive applications in the synthesis of medicinal derivatives and natural products [1–3]. However, disadvantages of traditional methods namely the use of expensive Pd-base catalytic systems, reactions at elevated temperature, and deployment of toxic agents [4–6], have promoted researchers to develop C-N bond formation via facile approaches using Pd-free catalytic systems [7,8]. In this regard, inexpensive 3d transition metals comprising nickel [9,10], copper [11,12], iron [13] and cobalt [14–19] have been deployed to make advancements on this topic. In recent years, inexpensive and low toxic cobalt catalytic systems have garnered much attention as an alternative to Pd in the development of cross-coupling reactions [20–26]. One of the most important aspects of an appropriate catalyst is its facile recyclability as magnetic material which can be separated easily from the reaction media [27–29]; magnetic silica nanoparticles have unique properties such as magnetic susceptibility, low toxicity, and high stability [30,31]. Numerous reports on the preparation and applications of heterogeneous catalysts based on magnetic nanoparticles have appeared in the literature; but, most of them suffer from varied multi-steps and time-consuming production methods or employing expensive ligands [32]. Therefore, achieving a readily available and easily prepared catalytic system, especially for the synthesis of pharmaceutical compounds, would be a valuable addition. In recent years, application of ligated metal complex and pyrolysis process as a procedure for the preparation of metal-based nano catalysts has garnered attention [33–40]. The deployment of plentiful, low-cost, and renewable precursors is valuable for the preparation of sustainable and efficient nano catalyst. In this regard, chitosan, as a source of carbon and nitrogen, has been applied as a green and abundant material to prepare nano catalyst based on magnetic silica [41]. Chitosan (Ch) is derived from a key constituent of the exoskeletons of crustaceans [42,43], with advantages namely inexpensive and readily available material endowed with biodegradability which renders it a suitable choice for various applications [44,45]; carbonization of polysaccharides such as chitosan generate single layer N-doped graphene [46–49] and high-quality N-doped carbon nanosheets [50]. Based on our earlier experiences in developing cross-coupling reactions [51–55]; herein, we describe an efficient and facile C-N cross-coupling reaction as the main step in the synthesis of various derivatives of Abemaciclib and Fedratinib catalyzed by novel introduced cobalt catalytic system under conventional thermal and microwave (MW) irradiation conditions. Abemaciclib is known as a selective inhibitor of cyclin-dependent kinases (CDK) which is applied for the therapy of hormone-positive breast cancer [56]; Abemaciclib was approved by the FDA in 2017 as a combination drug for the treatment of breast cancer. Available procedures for the large-scale synthesis of Abemaciclib comprises Suzuki and C-N cross-coupling reaction. The C-N coupling reaction has been performed in the presence of high loading Pd-phosphine complex comprising Xantph as ligand and t-AmylOH as a solvent at 100 °C [57]. Another FDA-approved drug whose synthesis is based on C-N cross-coupling reaction is Fedratinib. It is applied for the treatment of myelofibrosis through the inhibition of JAK2 activity which leads to apoptosis and preventing cell division [58,59]. The main accepted large-scale synthesis of Fedratinib comprise Pd-catalyzed C-N cross-coupling reaction and acid-promoted SNAr reaction [60]; large-scale synthesis methods have used expensive and toxic Pd-catalyst. In view of the fact that the acceptable amounts of Pd in drug residues is set at the ppm level [61], there is a genuine incentive to develop alternative efficient Pd-free method to accomplish C-N cross-coupling reactions for the synthesis of Abemaciclib and Fedratinib (Scheme 1). However, providing an effective technique with high yield and reproducibility in the production process of pharmaceutical compounds is a challenging task. The synthesis of several derivatives of aforementioned drugs are explored herein for the first time. Moreover, considering the effect of structure and properties of functional groups on biological activity, the potential binding interactions of synthesized derivatives with the binding site of target protein have also been investigated. Due to the higher costs and time-consuming traditional drug discovery processes [62], computational methods such as molecular docking have been explored which is based on ligand and target protein interaction [63–65]. The limited existing investigation of ATP binding pocket molecules and JAK2 inhibitor agents in molecular docking indicates the value of the presented research [66–71]. Results and discussion The silica was coated around the magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) through a simple and mild protocol. The complex of Co−Ch was prepared by mixing Co(NO3)2 6H2O and Ch in DMF. The magnetic silica was reacted with cobalt complex and stirred at 80 °C for 4-5 h. To generate the final solid catalyst which is labeled as Co-SiO2@MNPs, this solid was pyrolyzed at 800 °C (Scheme 2). The details of the synthesis procedure are provided in the supplemental data file. The prepared cobalt-based catalyst was characterized using various techniques. The morphology of the surface of the catalyst was investigated by field emission scanning electron microscopic (FE-SEM) and transmission electron microscopic (TEM) analyses. The SEM images indicated the surface roughness of dispersed nanoparticles on the magnetic silica bed (Fig. 1 a). The TEM images of the catalyst exhibited well-defined dispersed spherical nanoparticles and some aggregations were also observed (Fig. 1b). From the particle size histogram, the nanoparticle size is about 4–11 nm. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis (Fig. 2 a) was applied to identify the chemical states of cobalt. The peaks at 785.3 eV and 801.0 eV, is linked to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of the Co(0), respectively. The presence of Co3O4 was also confirmed through two major peaks of 780.6 (Co 2p3/2) and 796.0 eV (Co 2p1/2); so, both species of Co(0) and Co3O4 co-exist in the catalyst. The energy-dispersive X-ray (EDAX) spectra exhibited existing metals on the surface of the catalyst (Fig. 2b). In the X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern (Fig. 2a), the diffraction peak at 26 ° is related to SiO2 and peaks at 2 θ of 31, 38, 47, 50, and 64 ° are attributed to the Co3O4 and Co species which can be assigned to diffraction of the (220), (311), (111), (200), and (440) plane, respectively. The XRD pattern also indicated the magnetite crystalline structure of Fe3O4 with peaks attributed at 2 θ of 31.1 °, 38.6 °, 55.0 °, 57.4 °, and 63.1 that are related to (220), (222), (422), (511), and (440) plane, respectively. The vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) analysis affirms the magnetic properties of the catalyst (Fig. 2d) which is a suitable technique for facile removal of catalyst from the reaction media by using an external magnetic bar. Magnetic susceptibility measurements at 1 Hz were used for comparing the magnetic susceptibility of MNPs and coated MNPs as a final catalyst which required more time (10 h) for similar decreasing to the MNPs (Fig. 2e). To achieve a useful and efficient method to catalyze the C-N cross-coupling reaction as the main step of synthesizing of two mentioned drugs, Abemaciclib and Fedratinib, a simple C-N coupling reaction was selected as a model to optimize the reaction conditions; reaction of 4-methoxyaniline and 3-chloropyridine was performed to identify the best catalyst and ideally suitable reaction conditions. Initially, the reaction was performed in the presence of homogeneous cobalt salt and Ch in DMF, applying K2CO3 as a base, and at 100 °C, the conversion of the reaction was negligible (Table 1 , entry 1). Moreover, the lack of progress in the reaction by using magnetic silica nanoparticles indicated the critical role of cobalt (Table 1, entry 2). Interestingly, supporting cobalt nanoparticles on the surface of magnetic silica without applying any ligand exhibited low activity (Table 1, entry 3). The activity of the catalyst without a magnetic core (Table 1, entry 5) was like the main catalyst (Table 1, entry 6) which indicated no effect of the magnetic core. The model reaction was also performed in presence of MNPs without further modification, it was found inactive in this reaction (Table 1, entry 3), this result indicated the critical role of cobalt as catalytic active species. Moreover, the catalytic amount was also examined, and the optimum amount was found to be 20 mg (Table 1, entries 6–8). For attaining the best reaction conditions, the effect of varying the temperatures was investigated under the same reaction conditions; reaction performance at 65 °C was selected as optimized temperature because no significant improvement was observed at higher temperatures. To study the solvent effect, various solvents namely dimethylacetamide (DMA), dimethylformamide (DMF), N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), H2O/EtOH, and polyethylene glycol (PEG-200) were assessed. The influence of green, and available solvent, PEG-200, was found to be of utmost priority. Among various bases, K2CO3 appeared as the best option. The ensuing results from the optimization reactions are presented in Table 2 . Applying microwave (MW) irradiation diminished the reaction time significantly; so, the reaction conditions under MW irradiation such as temperature and power levels were also investigated. The best outcome was obtained deploying 20 mg catalyst, in PEG-200, using 400 W power at 65 °C. The general scope of both methods was studied with different aromatic amines to prepare a series of Fedratinib and Abemaciclib derivatives (Tables 3 and 4 ). Almost all of these reactions proceeded efficiently, and the results were compared together. As can be seen, MW-assisted reactions lead to completion in a shorter time period and afforded higher yields of products. In addition to the catalyst's excellent prowess, it can be easily separated from the reaction media by employing an external magnet bar. The results from the recycling study of the catalyst performed using a selected model reaction of 4-methoxyaniline and 3-chloropyridine, are presented in Table 5 . After completion of the reaction, the catalyst was separated and washed with hot ethanol, and applied in the next run; Co-SiO2@MNPs maintained its activity even after six successive runs. In view of the significant medicinal properties of the synthesized compounds, the ability to scale up synthesis is an important criterion for the introduced methods. Therefore, the scale-up synthesis of Fedratinib (Table 3, entry 1) was also examined at 10.0 mmol level, where the reaction stoichiometry was kept intact. These reactions proceeded successfully, and excellent yields of products were achieved; yield of products being 79% and 69% for conventional heating and MW irradiation, respectively. Herein, we report a sustainable, short, and efficient synthesis of novel derivatives of some significant anticancer compounds for the first time through sustainable means. Molecular docking studies Molecular docking simulations were performed using Auto Dock 4.2 [72]. The PDB files of proteins were taken from the Protein Data Bank (PDB file for JAK2: 6VNE and PDB file for CDK-6: 5L2S) [73,74] Polar hydrogens group and Kollman charges were added, and all water ions and the ligand were removed from the protein structure. A grid box size of 60 × 60 × 60 Å was centered on the macromolecule binding pocket with a grid spacing of a 0.375 nm. Three-dimensional structures of ligands were depicted in Marvin Sketch v5.7 and were saved in PDB format [75]. The atomic charges were determined according to Gasteiger-Marsili method [76]. In both of the proteins (JAK2 and CDK-6), number of Lamarckian jobs was 50 runs, maximum number of energy evaluation was set 2.5 × 105, initial population was set to 150, and other parameters were set in their defaults. All the runs were sorted by the lowest binding energy and analyzed for the best conformation and orientation ligand at the active site of the protein. The docking was analyzed and visualized by both, the Accelrys Discovery Studio 2.5 and PyMOL [77,78]. According to standard drugs (Fedratinib and Abemaciclib), novel inhibitors were designed. The molecular docking of the designed ligands with JAK2 and CDK6 proteins were carried out in dlg files and the docking results were ordered by binding energy. The initial coordinates of the LY2835219 and 2TA ligands were used as the reference and the root-mean-square deviation (RMSD) was obtained between the valid conformations and docked ligands at less than 2 Å. All compounds were completely sited in the active site. The 2TA ligand was docked with the JAK2 protein in order to determine this ligand as JAK2 inhibitor. The validation test was accomplished. The analysis of all docked poses showed that the 2TA ligand was located in the binding pocket. Hydrophobic contacts were observed between the residues Leu855, Gly856, Val 863, Ala880, Met929, Glu930, Tyr931, Leu932, Pro933, Gly935, Asp939, Tyr940, Lys943, Arg980 and Leu983, hydrogen bonds between the ligand Leu855, Leu932, Pro933, Ser936, Asp939, Asn981, Gly993 and Asp994 of JAK2 protein. The five mentioned compounds were located in the binding pocket, Compound 5 displayed good docking rating (− 10.23 kcal/mol) and a hydrogen bond were formed with amino acids (Leu932, Asp939 and Leu855). The molecular docking results are provided in Table 6 . These compounds showed better docked score than the standard drug and docking results show that it could inhibit enzyme with cytotoxic activity. Two and three-dimensional analysis for novel inhibitors are shown in Scheme 3 . The LY2835219 ligand was docked with the CDK6 protein to establish this ligand as a CDK6 inhibitor. The validation test was performed, and the analysis of all docked states showed that ligand LY2835219 was located in the binding pocket. Hydrophobic contacts were observed between the residues Tyr24, Ala41, Val77, His100, Asp104, Thr107, Leu152 and, Ala162 and hydrogen bonds between the ligand and Lys43, His100, Val101, Gln103, Asp163 of CDK6 protein. All compounds were perfectly placed in the binding pocket. All of the 50 docked poses with the lowest connection energy were ranked and analyzed. The docking results with interacting residues of the docked compounds and standard drug are presented in Table 7 . These compounds offered the binding energy in the range of −8.8 kcal/mol–11.17 kcal/mol. Among the four mentioned compounds, structure 5 demonstrated the lowest binding energy. These compounds showed the better docked score than the standard drug and docking results show that it could inhibit enzyme with cytotoxic activity. The docking results also correlate to their anticancer activity results. Two and three-dimensional analyses are provided in the supplementary data file, the most interacted derivatives are depicted in Scheme 4 . Conclusion Cobalt nanoparticles were immobilized on silica through generated Ch cobalt complex and pyrolysis process. We demonstrated the application of this Pd/Cu-free catalyst to produce derivatives of Fedratinib and Abemaciclib, recently FDA-approved anti-cancer agents, through C-N cross-coupling reactions for the first time. Both, the conventional heating, and MW-irradiation conditions were used with their outcomes compared, affording the excellent yield of products. The introduced technique is not only facile, mild, and green but also deploys a sustainable and recyclable catalyst. The potential cytotoxic activity of synthesized derivatives was investigated by molecular docking studies through their interaction with JAK2 and CDK6 protein. The synthesis studies and ensuing results indicated the generality of the presented procedure and the outcomes of the docking study affirmed their promising potential anticancer properties. coredata.dc:description: Herein, chitosan as an inexpensive, abundant, and biodegradable bio-material, produced from a key constituent of the exoskeletons of crustaceans, was used to generate the cobalt-based magnetic silica nanocomposite for the performance of the C-N cross-coupling reaction as the main step of the synthesis of Abemaciclib and Fedratinibs. Several derivatives of these recently FDA-approved anti-cancer drugs were synthesized for the first time by using Pd/Cu-free co-catalyzed under both, the conventional heating and microwave (MW) irradiation conditions. The potential anticancer activity of synthesized compounds was investigated by molecular docking study.
coredata.dc:title: Sustainable synthesis of potential antitumor new derivatives of Abemaciclib and Fedratinib via C-N cross coupling reactions using Pd/Cu-free Co-catalyst
